A king who feels nothing when his men die is no king worth following. But there is a difference between carrying the weight of responsibility and drowning in guilt that serves no one. You say you think about them. That you will never totally forget them. Good. Remember their faces when you next command a fleet. Remember them when you are tempted to skip a drill because the men are tired or the weather is fair. Let their deaths teach you. But do not let their deaths consume you. That is not penance. That is pride wearing the mask of humility—the belief that you should have been able to control the wind and the waves. Is there more you wish to confess? Or shall we speak of your heart as it stands tonight—on the eve of whatever tomorrow brings?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Another thing father. I think about what I should do. In my mind, I have to do things sometimes, have to take certain risks. You disagree?

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: You think about what you should do. You have to take certain risks. And you ask if I disagree. An hour ago, you told me that your confessor need not examine your every move and motive. You said you would let the divine inspire you as it has done so many times before. And now, in the confessional, you ask me whether I disagree with the risks you take. Which is it, my son? Do you wish me to examine? Or do you wish me to bless what you have already decided?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: This afternoon we were not in the confessional. There is a difference. When I am in the world, I focus on worldly things. Never do I totally neglect my soul but I reserve moments such as these to thoroughly examine myself. Being without sin is not a purpose in itself. It are my actions that matter and actions originating from sin are wrong actions. Also, there is a reason the confessional is confidential. When we are alone, I feel free to speak my doubts and failures. When we are in company of others, other things are required of me. Do you understand my position?

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: I understand your position. You reserve the confessional for examination. You reserve the world for action. In here, you speak your doubts. Out there, you silence them so that others may follow a king who does not doubt. And tonight you have confessed negligence in the matter of the fleet, and resolved to do better. This is good. But you also asked me a question. Whether I disagree with the risks you take. You have not yet told me what sin you are confessing when you ask this. Are you confessing doubt? Pride? Fear? Or are you asking your confessor to tell you that your risks are righteous so that you may march tomorrow with a quieter heart?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Ha! No, of course not father. And thank you for your question. I think that I want to take a moment to examine to what degree pride is present in my soul. I confess it is always there. How can it not? When I appear with my beautiful daughter and wife, i feel tremendous pride and love. But also pride. Leading them into mass at the head of my knights even more so. Likewise, there is also a purpose to this action. I want to stir up the papacy a bit and create some ripples in the water so I can better speak with and understand their thinking. When I ask you if you approve...I think what I am actually asking is... what part of this action is pride and how can I make my action more pure and without pride?

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: Ah. You ask me to separate the pride from the purpose. To tell you which threads are sin and which are righteousness, so that you may pluck out the one and keep the other. I cannot do this for you. No confessor can. The threads are woven too tightly. The same hand that reaches for the sword in pride also reaches for it in duty. The same heart that swells before the cheering crowd swells also with love for the men who follow you. But I will ask you this. Tomorrow, when you stand before your men in the shadow of St. Peter's—when the Pope's windows look down upon you and all of Rome watches—if God were to whisper in your ear, 'Set aside this display. Go to Eugenius quietly, as a pilgrim, and speak with him as one Christian to another'... Would you obey? Or would you explain to God why the ripples in the water are necessary?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Pride is appearing before others with Lucia and thinking: 'See this beautiful woman? She is my wife. She is more beautiful than yours and thus I am better than you.' Grace is admiring her beauty and sharp mind with others. They are God's gifts who are not mine but are shared with everyone. Pride is presenting my Catalina to others, demonstrating how charming, intelligent and willfull she is. She is smarter than your daughter, admire her and praise her for praising her is praise for me. Grace is letting others share in the pride of fatherhood. When I let her interact with or give her into care of others, we can all be proud of her and her personality. Pride is walking 600 knights into Rome to dominate. Grace is letting others share in our devotion. I will pray on this further father. Any more words of wisdom for this sinner?

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: You have a gift for finding the right words, my son. You always have. You have confessed negligence in the matter of the fleet. For this, I absolve you. Say five Pater Nosters for the souls of the seventy-five, and resolve to do better. Ego te absolvo a peccatis tuis, in nomine Patris, et Filii, et Spiritus Sancti. Amen.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Then he rises, his knees cracking softly. He stands looking down at you for a moment, his face half in shadow.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: Tomorrow you will learn whether you walk those six hundred men into Rome in pride or in grace. No words spoken tonight can settle that question. Only the walking will tell. I will march with you. And I will watch. And when it is done, we will speak again.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He leaves you alone with the Madonna and the candles and the silence.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Gracias father. Good night.

encounters.recap: Juan confesses to Fray Hernando about the seventy-five men lost in the storm, accepting responsibility for inadequate preparation. The conversation turns to Juan's struggle with pride versus divine purpose in his planned march through Rome tomorrow. Hernando absolves Juan for the fleet's losses but challenges him to discern whether his actions stem from pride or grace, refusing to provide easy answers and promising to watch Juan's march with keen spiritual scrutiny.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The corridor from the chapel winds through the palazzo's ground floor, past the kitchens where servants are banking fires for the night, up a narrow staircase to the chambers the household has prepared for the royal family. The door to your chambers stands slightly ajar. Candlelight spills into the hallway, warm against the cool stone. Inside, Lucia sits at a small writing desk near the window, a letter half-composed before her. She wears a simple linen shift, her dark hair unbound and falling past her shoulders. At the sound of your entrance, she sets down her quill but does not rise immediately.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Catalina is asleep. It took three stories and a promise that she could wave at the Pope tomorrow. I did not know what else to tell her. The servants are talking about an early departure. Captain Fernán has sent riders to San Paolo and to St. Peter's.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She turns in her chair to face you fully. In the candlelight, you can see the subtle changes that pregnancy has begun to work—a softness in her face, a careful way she holds herself.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Six hundred men to Mass, husband. And my inquiry to the Camera produced nothing. And Fray Hernando returned from Cardinal Orsini looking like a man who had been shown a closed door. Will you tell me what you are thinking? Or shall I learn tomorrow along with the rest of Rome?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Come and sit with me love. I want to talk to you about this all. And about what I just discussed with Fray Hernando. I do not know what will happen actually. Truly I dont. I want to announce our presence and make a speech about why we are here probably. And we will see. Maybe there is a cardinal there, a moment in the mass where I can make a connection, get an invitation, get someone's attention... I dont know yet. We will see.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Lucia lets you take her hand, lets you guide her to the bed. She sits beside you, her fingers cool against your palm. For a moment she is silent, listening.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: We will see. In Florence, when my father negotiated with other banking houses, he would spend weeks preparing. He would know what the other party wanted before he entered the room. He would know their debts, their fears, their children's marriages, their mistresses' names. He said that a man who walks into a negotiation without knowing what he wants walks out with whatever the other man decides to give him. You spoke with Fray Hernando about pride and grace. What did he say?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: And I agree completely. I have a few days at maximum before the pope summons me. If he does, I cannot delay. We have not the time to prepare for weeks. Tomorrow at the mass, we are not conducting an audience, I hope it will aid us in our preparation.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Lucia nods slowly at your explanation. Her hand remains in yours, but her eyes search your face.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Preparation. Yes. I understand this. Creating ripples, as you said. Seeing who reacts and how. But I asked you what Fray Hernando said. About pride and grace. And you answered me about tactics. What troubles your confessor, husband? What troubles you?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: He told me I have a gift for beautiful words, that I always have had this gift. I spent some time separating pride from grace in my actions tomorrow. I told him that: Pride is appearing before others with Lucia and thinking: 'See this beautiful woman? She is my wife. She is more beautiful than yours and thus I am better than you.' Grace is admiring her beauty and sharp mind with others. They are God's gifts who are not mine but are shared with everyone. Pride is presenting my Catalina to others, demonstrating how charming, intelligent and willfull she is. She is smarter than your daughter, admire her and praise her for praising her is praise for me. Grace is letting others share in the pride of fatherhood. When I let her interact with or give her into care of others, we can all be proud of her and her personality. Pride is walking 600 knights into Rome to dominate. Grace is letting others share in our devotion. Maybe I am a complicated man, I dont know. What do you think?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Lucia is quiet for a long moment. The candle on the writing desk flickers, sending shadows dancing across the bedchamber walls.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: You told him all that. Those words. About me, about Catalina, about grace and sharing. And he told you that you have a gift for beautiful words. Juan. I am not a lesson in theology. I am not an example you bring to confession to demonstrate that you understand the difference between pride and grace.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She withdraws her hand from yours—not sharply, but deliberately. She folds both hands in her lap, looking down at them. When she looks up, her expression is difficult to read. She rises from the bed and moves to the window, her shift pale in the darkness.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: When you speak of me that way—'her beauty and sharp mind are God's gifts to be shared with everyone'—do you hear yourself? I am your wife. Not a painting in a church for pilgrims to admire. You asked what I think. I think your confessor was not praising your beautiful words. I think he was warning you about them.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: You are not a trophy or painting Lucia. You never have been. To treat you as such would be exactly the sin I want to guard myself against. What I mean is that when you make a clever joke or remark and make me and others laugh, I am glad for me and others that they can see how wonderful you are. What warning could he have given me about them? I dont understand. Surely being good with words is no sin?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Lucia stands by the window, her arms still crossed. The moonlight catches the curve of her cheek, the slight furrow between her brows.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: I am not your confessor, Juan. If you want Fray Hernando's warning explained, ask Fray Hernando. It is late. I am tired. Your child makes me tired in ways I did not expect. And tomorrow you will march six hundred men to St. Peter's and make a speech you have not yet written, trusting that God will provide the words.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She looks at you—really looks, the way she did in those early days in Toledo when you were both still learning each other.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: I am not afraid for you, husband. I have seen what you can do. I watched you win Barcelona with a letter written on the spot. But tonight I do not want to talk about pride and grace and beautiful words. I want to know if my husband is well. If he is frightened. If he is certain. If he is uncertain. Tell me something true. Something without beautiful words.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Im swinging the hammer love. And my only fear is that I may smash things that I did not intend to. That the sparks ignite and start a fire. But it is done. Enough talk. I am well, let me now take care of you. Do you want something to drink? To eat?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Lucia lets you guide her into the bed, arranging the pillows behind her back. The tension in her shoulders eases as she settles against them. She looks younger like this, in the candlelight, without the formal gowns and the careful posture of a queen.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Water. Just water.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: You pour from the clay pitcher on the side table. She drinks slowly, watching you over the rim of the cup.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Swinging the hammer. My husband the blacksmith. Forging kingdoms on the anvil of St. Peter's.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She reaches for your hand and pulls you down to sit beside her on the bed.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: I will not march with you tomorrow. Six hundred men and a pregnant woman waddling behind—it does not make the picture you want. But Catalina will be disappointed. She has been promised a Pope to wave at. I will watch from somewhere. Perhaps the Castel Sant'Angelo, if we can arrange it. Or one of the houses near the piazza. Someone should be watching who is not marching. Someone should see how Rome reacts.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: A yawn catches her. She fights it, unsuccessfully.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Wake me before you go. Even if it is dark. I want to see you before...

encounters.recap: In an intimate evening conversation, Juan shares his theological reflections on pride versus grace with Lucia, who challenges him for treating her as a philosophical example rather than his wife. Their discussion reveals tensions between his grand rhetoric and personal relationships, ending with Lucia's practical support despite her concerns about his approach to the upcoming papal audience.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The pre-dawn darkness still fills the palazzo when you rise. Lucia stirs as you leave the bed but does not wake fully—you press a kiss to her forehead and she murmurs something in Italian, already sinking back into sleep. The corridor is cold, the stone floors like ice beneath your feet. A single servant is awake, lighting candles in the hallway. She curtsies hastily when she sees you, eyes wide at the sight of the King of Castile wandering his own chambers in the dark.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Catalina's room is two doors down, a small chamber she shares with her nursemaid. You ease the door open. The nursemaid sleeps on a pallet near the wall, snoring softly. Catalina lies in a small bed fitted with wooden rails to keep her from tumbling out—a battle she wages nightly, by all accounts. She has kicked off her blankets. One arm clutches a wooden horse that Captain Fernán carved for her aboard the Princesa Catalina. Her dark hair—Lucia's hair, Isabel's hair—fans across the pillow. At two years old, she has the face of both mothers somehow. Isabel's brow, Lucia's mouth. Your own stubborn jaw already emerging from the soft roundness of babyhood.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The palazzo stirs to life around you as servants are roused and candles lit. The household has received word—they know something significant happens today, even if they do not know precisely what. Your squire helps you into the armor. The familiar weight settles onto your shoulders—breastplate, pauldrons, vambraces. Good Castilian steel, burnished but not ostentatious. You leave the coif and helmet on their stand. Your head will be bare, your face visible. A king attending Mass, not a warrior preparing for battle.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Are we seeing the Pope, Papá? Lucia-mama said I could wave.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: You return to your chambers as promised. Lucia is awake now, sitting up in bed, a shawl around her shoulders against the morning chill. She looks at you in your armor—the steel catching the candlelight, your head bare, your face set with purpose.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: There he is. The hammer.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She rises, moves to you, places one hand against the cold metal of your breastplate.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: I will watch from the Castel Sant'Angelo. The Medici agent is arranging it. Come back to me, Juan. Whatever happens at St. Peter's—come back.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Dont worry love, im not going to war. Can I bring you something when I return?

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Roman oranges. The blood oranges. I have been craving them since we arrived, and the ones the servants brought yesterday were sour. And news. Bring me news of what happened, before the rumors reach me. Your child and I will be waiting.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: From down the corridor, you hear Catalina's voice rising in imperious demand—something about her wooden horse and why it cannot come to see the Pope. Lucia laughs softly.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Go. Before your daughter stages her own rebellion.

encounters.recap: In the pre-dawn hours, Juan rises to prepare for a significant papal mass. He visits sleeping Catalina, then dons his armor while leaving his helmet behind to appear as a king attending mass rather than a warrior. After tender farewells with Lucia, who will watch from Castel Sant'Angelo, he departs to join his knights for their march to St. Peter's.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The sky is grey with early dawn when you arrive at San Paolo fuori le Mura, Catalina bundled in a cloak and riding before you on the saddle. She has been promised that she may wave at the Pope, and this promise has transformed her usual morning ill-temper into focused determination. The basilica's great courtyard is already alive with movement. Six hundred men in white tabards—no, five hundred and ninety-one, you remind yourself, always remember the seventy-five—form into ranks with the quiet efficiency of veterans. No shouted commands. No chaos. These men have marched together, fought together, watched brothers die together. They know their places.

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: The Vatican raised no objection, Your Majesty. The archpriest sent word that pilgrims are always welcome at St. Peter's. He also mentioned that His Holiness's household has been informed of our coming. I suspect we will have observers.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The white banner of the crusade—the same banner that flew over Granada, that has been carried across half of Christendom—unfurls in the morning breeze. Fray Hernando appears at your side, grey habit freshly brushed, his face composed and unreadable. Marco Tornesi, Andrea Vescovi, Giovanni Rossi, Brother Guillem—the old names, the first crusaders, the survivors of Barcelona and Seville and the long bloody road to Granada—take their places in the formation.

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: The men are ready, Your Majesty.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: You have done this before—entered this city at the head of armed men. But that was 1430, a different Pope, a different purpose. Then you came seeking blessing for a crusade not yet begun. Now you come having finished one, carrying another on your shoulders. The route takes you through the Trastevere, across the Tiber, through the Campo de' Fiori where merchants setting up their stalls stop to stare. Six hundred men in white, marching in silence, the crusade banner snapping overhead. No drums. No trumpets. Only the rhythmic tread of boots on Roman cobblestones. Romans emerge from doorways, lean from windows. You hear murmuring—crociati, Castiglia, Granada. An old woman crosses herself. A boy runs alongside the column for a hundred yards before his mother drags him back. Catalina, held before you on the saddle, waves at everyone with indiscriminate enthusiasm.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The ancient basilica—Constantine's church, a thousand years old, the heart of Christendom—dominates the Vatican Hill. Scaffolding clings to portions of its facade; the building has been under perpetual renovation for decades. But the great doors stand open, and the atrium called the Paradiso spreads before them, colonnaded and vast. Your column halts in the piazza. The men maintain formation, silent, disciplined. Faces appear in the windows of the Apostolic Palace. You cannot make out features at this distance, but you feel the weight of watching eyes. A priest emerges from the basilica—elderly, dignified, wearing the vestments of a canon of St. Peter's. He approaches with measured steps.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Your Majesty of Castile. The Chapter of St. Peter welcomes you and your... companions... to Mass. If you will follow me, we have prepared space in the nave.

encounters.recap: Juan leads his 591 crusaders in a ceremonial march through Rome to St. Peter's Basilica. The disciplined column moves silently through the city streets, drawing crowds and attention, before arriving at the Vatican where they are formally welcomed by the cathedral chapter for Mass.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: You enter the basilica with Catalina in your arms. She squirms but subsides when you remind her of the promise—quiet, or Donna Francesca takes her outside. Her small hand grips the collar of your breastplate as her eyes go wide at the vastness of the space. The nave of St. Peter's stretches before you, a forest of ancient columns leading toward the high altar and the baldachin that marks the Apostle's tomb. Morning light filters through high windows, casting long shadows across mosaic floors worn smooth by a thousand years of pilgrims' feet. Your men file in behind you, filling the nave with white. The sound of their boots echoes off stone walls. They do not kneel yet—they wait for your lead.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The church is not empty, but neither is it full. Ordinary Romans occupy the side aisles—women in dark shawls, tradesmen in work clothes, a few beggars hoping for alms. They press back against the walls as your column enters, crossing themselves, whispering to each other. Near the front, a cluster of clergy in choir dress—canons of St. Peter's, you assume, the priests who serve this basilica daily. They watch your arrival with carefully composed faces. On the left side, near a pillar: A man in cardinal's red, elderly, thin-faced, sitting alone on a bench. You do not recognize him. He does not look at you—his eyes remain fixed on a book of hours in his lap, as if six hundred armed pilgrims entering the church were beneath his notice. Near the confessionals: Two younger clergy in the black robes of papal secretaries. They are watching intently, and one writes something in a small notebook. Observers. Reporters. Someone will know everything that happens here within the hour. Notably absent: Cardinal Orsini. Cardinal Capranica. Any face you recognize from your visit in 1430, from the courts of Martin V or the early months of Eugenius's reign. The Vatican has sent no one of significance to greet you.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Is that where the Pope lives, Papá?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: He lives in a house nearby love. We can wave at him later. You are very good at waving. Stay here for a moment.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: You pass Catalina to Donna Francesca, who has followed you inside. The child protests briefly but is distracted by the play of colored light through a window. You make your way forward, your armor drawing stares from the Roman worshippers who have pressed themselves against the walls. Near the sacristy entrance, you find a priest in the vestments of a celebrant—chasuble of white and gold, stole already in place. He is perhaps fifty, with the soft hands of a man who has spent his life with books and sacraments rather than swords. He is speaking quietly with two younger priests, reviewing what appears to be the order of service.

exchanges.speaker: canon_giuliano_della_rovere
exchanges.text: Your Majesty. I am Canon Giuliano Della Rovere. I will be celebrating Mass this morning. We were not expecting quite so many communicants. The distribution of the Eucharist will take some time. Is there something Your Majesty requires before we begin?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Thank you for receiving me and my company. My knights will conduct themselves orderly. For us from Castille, being able to receive mass in this magnificent church means a lot. If I may place one request, then I hope our thoughts and prayers will go to the lost brothers at sea. My company has lost about 75 knights on our way here and we still feel their loss sharply.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Canon Della Rovere's expression shifts—a slight softening around the eyes. Whatever his instructions, whatever his caution, he is still a priest. The dead have claims that politics cannot entirely silence.

exchanges.speaker: canon_giuliano_della_rovere
exchanges.text: Seventy-five souls lost at sea. The Mass includes prayers for the faithful departed. I will remember your fallen brothers during the Memento for the Dead. They will not be named individually—we have not the time, and I do not have their names. But God knows them, even if I do not. Is there anything else, Your Majesty? We should begin. The hour grows late.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I thank you father for your considerations. Have a blessed service.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Behind you, five hundred and ninety-one men stand in silence, waiting. The candles on the high altar flicker. The two papal secretaries continue to watch from near the confessionals, one still writing in his notebook.

encounters.recap: Juan attends Mass at St. Peter's Basilica with 591 knights and his daughter Catalina. The Vatican sends no high officials, but Canon Giuliano Della Rovere agrees to include prayers for Juan's 75 fallen knights during the service. Papal secretaries observe and record the proceedings.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Mass proceeds. Canon Della Rovere celebrates with careful competence—neither rushed nor lingering, neither warm nor cold. His homily touches on pilgrimage, on the value of sacred journeys, on the blessings that await those who seek holy places. Generic words that could apply to any group of travelers. He does not mention Granada. He does not mention crusade. He does not mention Constantinople. During the Memento for the Dead, he pauses and says: "We remember those souls who perished at sea, faithful servants on their journey to do God's work. May perpetual light shine upon them." It is brief. It is dignified. It is the minimum he could do while still honoring your request.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Your knights kneel and rise in perfect unison. They receive communion in silence, row by row, the distribution taking nearly half an hour. The Romans pressed against the walls watch with wide eyes—they have never seen anything quite like this. Five hundred and ninety-one men moving as one body, white tabards bright against the ancient stone. Catalina behaves better than you feared. She grows restless during the Liturgy of the Word, squirming against your armor, but Donna Francesca produces a small ribbon from somewhere and the child is distracted. During the elevation of the Host, she grows still and watches the raised bread with something like wonder. She does not call out. She does not wave. She simply watches.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The elderly cardinal in red never once looks at you. His eyes remain fixed on his book of hours throughout. When the final blessing is given, he rises and departs through a side door without acknowledgment. The papal secretaries close their notebooks and slip away toward the Apostolic Palace. As your knights begin to file out into the Paradiso, you notice movement near the sacristy. The hooded Dominican—the one who watched from the shadows throughout the Mass—has moved. Not toward you. Toward Fray Hernando.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The two friars speak briefly, their voices too low to carry over the shuffle of boots and the murmur of departing worshippers. Fray Hernando's face remains neutral, revealing nothing. The Dominican keeps his hood raised, his features obscured. The conversation lasts perhaps thirty seconds. Then the Dominican turns and disappears through a door near the confessionals. Gone.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Fray Hernando makes his way to your side as you emerge into the morning light of the Paradiso. Catalina is demanding to know when she can wave at the Pope. The knights are reforming into column. Roman onlookers—a modest crowd, curious but not large—watch from the edges of the piazza.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: A brother from Santa Maria sopra Minerva. The Dominican house. He says there are those in the city who would speak with you privately. Away from Vatican eyes. He did not say who. He did not say why. He said only that if you are interested, you should send word to the priory. Ask for Brother Tomás de Torquemada.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: I know the name. He is Spanish. From Valladolid. He has served the Inquisition in Aragon. What he is doing in Rome, or whom he represents, I cannot say.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The crusade banner snaps in the morning breeze above your knights. The windows of the Apostolic Palace remain shuttered.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Arrange the meeting. Now lets first go outside where I will address the company.

roll.outcome: Dominican approaches Fray Hernando with cryptic invitation for private meeting away from Vatican oversight

encounters.recap: During Mass at St. Peter's, a mysterious Dominican friar approaches Fray Hernando with a cryptic message. The friar, representing unknown parties, requests a private meeting away from Vatican eyes and identifies himself through Brother Tomás de Torquemada at Santa Maria sopra Minerva. Juan agrees to arrange the meeting after addressing his knights.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: You emerge into the Paradiso—the great colonnaded atrium before St. Peter's. The morning sun has risen above the rooftops now, casting long shadows across the worn paving stones. The air smells of incense from the basilica behind you and bread from the bakers' stalls beyond the piazza.

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: Your Majesty?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Form the men. With the banner. I will address them.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Within minutes, the column transforms into a formation—a broad rectangle facing the basilica steps where you stand. The white banner of the crusade rises at the center, held by a veteran whose name you should remember but cannot in this moment. Five hundred and ninety-one faces look up at you, weathered by sun and salt and the long road from Granada. The Roman crowd has grown. Word spreads quickly in this city. Perhaps two hundred people now ring the edges of the piazza—merchants abandoning their stalls, servants pausing on errands, beggars hoping for coin, mothers with children on their hips. They watch in silence, uncertain what they are witnessing. Above and behind them, the windows of the Apostolic Palace. Most remain shuttered. But here and there, a curtain has been drawn aside. Faces watch from the shadows.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Is Papá going to talk loud?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The men wait. Rome waits. The Vatican watches.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Brothers, we stand here, united in faith at the center of our church in this world. A beautiful moment I will cherish and remember. And many more beautiful moments will yet come. We are on quite a journey together and if all goes according to plan, we will visit many more wonderful places. I pray you remember them and keep them in your heart so that when we breathe our last breath, our thoughts wonder off to all the things we have done in the name of our faith and the beautiful things we have seen in his service. We are on a mission as well. Rome is our first stop as we travel to Constantinople. I have already met our holy father the pope last year and I have since visited Basel at his request. Much has happened since and I look forward to discuss with him how we can further solidify our church and our faith. Because the challenges require us to make use of every shred of faith we have available to us. Rest and relax for the coming days. We will leave after I have concluded my business with the holy father and we will sail for Naples. And we make sure we are prepared for any storm. Our recent experience teaches us to be humble. Sons of Castille, I thank you for your service. May we discover many more wonders in the days and years to come. I dismiss the company.

encounters.recap: Juan addresses his assembled troops in St. Peter's Paradiso, speaking of their mission to Constantinople and their upcoming departure for Naples. The speech takes place before a growing crowd of Romans and under the watchful eyes of the Vatican.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Your voice carries across the Paradiso, echoing off the ancient colonnades. The knights listen in silence—the disciplined silence of men who have learned to stand and wait through long campaigns. When you speak of the lost brothers, heads bow. When you mention Constantinople, a few hands make the sign of the cross. When you dismiss them, the formation holds for a heartbeat longer than necessary, as if reluctant to break.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Then Captain Fernán gives the signal, and the white rectangle dissolves into clusters of men, stretching legs, speaking quietly among themselves, looking up at the basilica and the Vatican windows with the expressions of pilgrims who have finally reached a long-sought destination.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Roman crowd does not disperse. Two hundred souls—perhaps more now, the edges of the piazza continuing to fill—linger in the morning light. They do not cheer. They do not jeer. They talk among themselves, voices carrying in fragments across the worn stones.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Near the colonnade, an old man in a butcher's stained apron speaks loudly, addressing no one in particular and everyone at once. His voice has the carrying quality of a Roman who has spent decades shouting over market noise.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: "He speaks of faith, not politics. When did we last hear that from anyone who visited the Vatican?" A few people laugh—the knowing laughter of those who have lived their lives in the shadow of the Apostolic Palace and have learned to read its moods. "The Spanish king talks of wonder and beautiful moments," the butcher continues, warming to his audience. "The cardinals talk of annates and precedence. You tell me which one sounds more like a Christian."

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Papá talked loud. Can we wave at the Pope now?

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: The men will return to San Paolo, Your Majesty, unless you have other orders. They're in good spirits. The Romans seem... curious. Not hostile. Not welcoming. Curious. No word from within. No messenger. No acknowledgment.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The morning sun climbs higher. The bells of St. Peter's remain silent. The Vatican keeps its own counsel. But in the piazza below its windows, Romans are still talking. Still watching. Still wondering what to make of the King of Castile who marched six hundred men to church and spoke of keeping beautiful moments in the heart.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Let the men rest. Tell me if they require anything. I dont want them to go hungry again. This is their chance to get rest before we will be at sea again for quite some while.

roll.outcome: Moderate crowd reception. Romans remain curious and engaged, discussing the speech favorably but Vatican offers no acknowledgment.

encounters.recap: After Juan's speech to his knights in St. Peter's Paradiso, the Roman crowd lingers and discusses his words favorably, particularly praising his focus on faith over politics. The Vatican remains silent with no official response, but the common people show curiosity and interest in the Spanish king who spoke of wonder and beautiful moments.

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: I'll see to it, Your Majesty. The men have coin from their service—the Roman merchants will be happy to take it. But I'll make sure no one goes without. They're proud, sire. Of this morning. Of being here. Whatever comes of it... they'll remember standing in this piazza.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He withdraws to organize the return to San Paolo. You lift Catalina onto your armored shoulder. She is heavier than she was a year ago—growing fast, as children do. Her small hands grip the edge of your pauldron for balance, and she looks where you point. The Apostolic Palace rises above the piazza, its Renaissance facade warm in the morning sun. Windows in rows, some shuttered, some dark, some with curtains that may or may not conceal watching eyes.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: That one? The Pope lives there?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She considers this information with the grave seriousness of a two-year-old evaluating important facts. Then she waves. Not a tentative wave. Not a shy flutter of fingers. A full-armed, enthusiastic wave, the kind she has been practicing on everyone from Roman street vendors to Castilian knights. Her whole body gets involved, nearly unbalancing herself from your shoulder.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Hello Pope! Hello! We came to see you!

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: A ripple of laughter passes through the nearby Romans. The old butcher grins. A woman clutches her companion's arm, delighted. Even a few of your dispersing knights turn to watch, smiles breaking through weathered faces. For a long moment, nothing happens. The Vatican windows remain as they were—shuttered, curtained, silent. Then— A curtain moves. Third floor, near the corner. A hand appears—pale, indistinct at this distance—and makes a small gesture. A wave? A blessing? A simple acknowledgment that a child's voice has carried across the piazza? It lasts only a moment. Then the curtain falls back into place. Catalina bounces on your shoulder with satisfaction.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: He waved back, Papá! Did you see? The Pope waved at me!

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Whether it was the Pope, or a cardinal, or a curious secretary, you cannot say. But your daughter is certain. And in the piazza below the Vatican windows, Romans are pointing and murmuring, having seen what she saw. The King of Castile's daughter waved at the Apostolic Palace. And someone waved back.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: You have done so wonderful Catalina! You can wave really well.

encounters.recap: Catalina enthusiastically waves at the Apostolic Palace from Juan's shoulder, calling out to the Pope. After a moment, someone in a third-floor window waves back, delighting both the child and the watching Romans in the piazza.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: You find Fray Hernando near the edge of the piazza, deep in conversation with a bread seller. Or rather, the bread seller is deep in conversation with him—a stout Roman woman pressing a fresh loaf into the Franciscan's hands and refusing payment with voluble Italian gestures. Hernando accepts with the weary grace of a man who has learned that arguing with Roman generosity is futile. He sees your approach and extracts himself, tucking the bread into his habit.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: The message has been sent. A boy carried it to Santa Maria sopra Minerva. The reply came quickly. Brother Tomás will receive us at the priory. Now, if you wish. He was... eager. More eager than I would expect from a Dominican receiving a foreign king unannounced.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The walk to Santa Maria sopra Minerva takes you through the heart of Rome. You shed the trappings of royal procession. No knights, no banner, no formation. Just a king in armor, a Franciscan in grey, and the ancient streets of the eternal city. The route passes the Pantheon—that vast drum of Roman engineering, now a church, its bronze doors green with age.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: The old gods live here still. Sanctified, but not forgotten.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Beyond it, a piazza opens, and there rises Santa Maria sopra Minerva. A Gothic church—rare in Rome—built literally atop the ruins of a temple to Minerva. The Dominicans have held it for two centuries. A young Dominican meets you at the door. He bows, says nothing, and leads you through the nave—past chapels thick with incense, past tombs of cardinals and nobles, past the blue-vaulted ceiling studded with golden stars—to a small door near the sacristy. The room is small, sparse, monastic. A desk, two chairs, a crucifix on the wall. A window looks out onto a modest courtyard where herbs grow in orderly rows. Brother Tomás de Torquemada rises as you enter. He is younger than you expected—perhaps thirty-five, no more than forty. Tall, gaunt, with the hollow cheeks of a man who fasts often and seriously. His Dominican habit is immaculate but worn, the white wool greyed from many washings. His eyes are the most striking feature: dark, intense, burning with something that might be faith or might be fever. He bows—correctly, but without flourish.

exchanges.speaker: tomas_de_torquemada
exchanges.text: Your Majesty. I am grateful you came. Please. Sit. We have much to discuss, and I am told Your Majesty's time in Rome may be brief.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Greetings. But explain first who you are and why you have asked for this meeting.

exchanges.speaker: tomas_de_torquemada
exchanges.text: Who I am. I am a friar of the Order of Preachers. I serve the Inquisition in Aragon under the authority of the Inquisitor General. I am in Rome on matters concerning my order. As for why I asked for this meeting... I watched you this morning, Your Majesty. From the back of St. Peter's. I watched six hundred men kneel as one. I watched you carry your daughter into the house of God. I listened to your speech in the piazza. And I asked myself: what manner of king marches an army to Mass and speaks of beautiful moments and humility? What manner of king conquers Granada and then sails for Constantinople? What manner of king visits Basel and Rome in the same year, as if he were trying to hold the Church together with his own two hands? I have questions, Your Majesty. Many questions. About Granada. About the conversos. About what you intend for the faith in your kingdom. But perhaps you did not come here to be interrogated by a Dominican. Perhaps you want something from me first. If so—ask. And we shall see if we can be of use to each other.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Fair enough. I have no questions as of yet. Maybe if you start with your questions, the rest will fall into place naturally. You want to know about conversos? What exactly?

exchanges.speaker: tomas_de_torquemada
exchanges.text: Commander Martín de Alcalá. Formerly Yusuf ibn Rashid. Thirty-two years commanding fortresses for Granada. Fought twenty-three battles against Christian armies. Now baptized. Now bearing a Christian name. Now, I am told, leading a delegation to Morocco on your behalf. Seventy men converted with him at Alcalá la Real. After watching sixteen thousand of their brothers die in a single afternoon. I am told it was... miraculous. A profound movement of the Holy Spirit. So my question, Your Majesty, is simple: How do you know? How do you know that Yusuf ibn Rashid—a man who killed Christians for thirty years—has truly found Christ? How do you know he is not merely a clever commander who saw which way the wind was blowing and chose survival? How do you know that when he prays, he prays to the Son and not to the god of Muhammad?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I do not. I cannot see the hearts of men. No one can. Maybe I am a secret muslim, who knows? I have learned that by speaking honestly with other men, you can usually get a good measure of them, especially when they hold nothing back. Confession helps as well.

exchanges.speaker: tomas_de_torquemada
exchanges.text: Honest conversation. Confession. A man who has watched sixteen thousand of his people slaughtered stands before the king who slaughtered them. His fortress is surrounded. His family's lives depend on the king's mercy. And you ask him to speak honestly about his faith. What do you imagine he will say, Your Majesty? I have spent years hearing confessions. In Aragon. In Valencia. From conversos whose grandfathers converted from Judaism a century ago. Do you know what I have learned? A man will confess what he believes his confessor wishes to hear. Especially when his life, his family, his property depend upon it. Commander Martín may be a true son of the Church. I pray that he is. But prayer is not policy, Your Majesty. And Granada now holds—what? Seventy thousand Muslims who have not converted, living beside how many who have?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Of course I am a firm son of Christ. In regards to Martin, even if he does still in his heart reaches for muhammed, he is loyal to me and my cause. His work in Morocco is valuable to me. If he betrays me and does not come back, I have lost not much. While he has much to gain from gaining my favor and being useful to me. Men are practical beings as well. But speak plainly, what do you propose? What can we do about the muslim population in Granada while the pope has forbidden forced conversions?

exchanges.speaker: tomas_de_torquemada
exchanges.text: The Pope has forbidden forced conversions. And so he should. A conversion made at sword-point is no conversion at all. The Church has always taught this. But there is a great distance, Your Majesty, between the sword at the throat and the open embrace of welcome. Seventy thousand Muslims in Granada. They live. They work. They pray to their god five times daily. They raise children who will pray to the same god. They marry among themselves and teach their sons that the Prophet is the final word. How many generations before they are the majority again? Not through conquest—through the cradle. The Pope forbids forced conversion. He does not forbid... conditions. He does not forbid a king from determining where mosques may stand. What trades Muslims may practice. What lands they may own. What positions they may hold. Whether their testimony holds weight against a Christian's in court. You asked what I propose. I propose nothing, Your Majesty. I am a humble Dominican with no authority in Castile. But I ask you this: in twenty years, what do you wish Granada to be? And what will you permit today that makes that future impossible?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I have made effort to destroy nearly all mosques in Granada. Some I have left standing in the first years of conquest to ease the transition. But soon they will all be churches. And we will slowly drive the muslims out of Granada of course. This takes time. And please speak freely. You have no authority in Castile but I do and you clearly have something to say. I would hear it.

encounters.recap: Brother Tomás de Torquemada, a Dominican serving the Aragonese Inquisition, meets with Juan II to probe his religious policies in Granada. Through careful questioning about converted Muslims like Commander Martín de Alcalá, Torquemada reveals his skepticism about the sincerity of mass conversions and advocates for systematic pressure to ensure religious conformity. Juan admits his pragmatic approach and reveals his plans to destroy all mosques and gradually expel Muslims from Granada.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: And please speak freely. You have no authority in Castille but I do and you clearly have something to say. I would hear it.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Torquemada is still for a moment. Then he returns to his chair and sits, and something in his posture shifts—less the interrogator, more the counselor.

exchanges.speaker: tomas_de_torquemada
exchanges.text: You destroy mosques. Good. You drive them out slowly. This is... prudent. But consider, Your Majesty. You drive them out—where? To Morocco? To Tunis? To the Ottoman lands? You send Commander Martín to Morocco now. In twenty years, you may face those same exiled Muslims returning with Moroccan armies, knowing every pass and fortress in Granada because they grew up there.

exchanges.speaker: tomas_de_torquemada
exchanges.text: And those who remain—those who convert to avoid exile—how will you know them from those who converted truly? They will attend Mass. They will baptize their children. They will eat pork when Christians are watching. And in their homes, behind closed doors, they will wash the baptismal water from their infants' heads and whisper the shahada over them.

exchanges.speaker: tomas_de_torquemada
exchanges.text: I have seen this, Your Majesty. In Aragon. With the Jews who converted a generation ago. Conversos who light candles on Friday nights. Who refuse to eat shellfish. Who marry only among themselves. Who are Christian in the streets and Jewish in their hearts.

exchanges.speaker: tomas_de_torquemada
exchanges.text: You asked what I propose. Very well. First—records. Every conversion documented. Every baptism recorded with witnesses. The names of godparents, the officiating priest, the date and place. A register that follows the converso and his descendants. Second—observation. Not persecution. Observation. Neighbors who report irregularities. Priests who note which conversos attend Mass faithfully and which find excuses. Patterns, Your Majesty. The apostate reveals himself through patterns. Third—investigation. When patterns emerge, when accusations accumulate, then—and only then—formal inquiry. Conducted by men trained to distinguish true faith from performance. Men who understand that the apostate will lie, and who know how to find truth regardless.

exchanges.speaker: tomas_de_torquemada
exchanges.text: This is not the sword at the throat. This is the shepherd watching his flock for wolves in sheep's clothing. The Pope cannot object to a king who documents baptisms, notices irregularities, and investigates accusations of apostasy. This is not forced conversion. This is the protection of the Church from those who would corrupt it from within.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Prudent measures. I know that having Castillians settle in Grenada is the only sure way to completely christianize the area in the long term. I have only just finished the conquest. Focus is on stability for now. Then the inquisition can move in and can start observing their habits. Do you have contacts with the Castillian inquisition? I will need their help.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Torquemada's expression does not change, but something stills in him—the stillness of a hunter who sees his quarry turn toward him.

exchanges.speaker: tomas_de_torquemada
exchanges.text: The Castilian Inquisition. It exists, Your Majesty. Bishops hold inquisitorial authority in their dioceses. Occasionally they exercise it. Occasionally. In Aragon, the Inquisition is... more developed. More systematic. We have experience with the converso question that Castile has been spared, until now.

exchanges.speaker: tomas_de_torquemada
exchanges.text: I have contacts, yes. In Aragon. Among the Dominicans who staff the tribunals. Among those who understand that this work requires training, method, patience. Whether such contacts would be useful in Castile depends upon what Your Majesty intends.

exchanges.speaker: tomas_de_torquemada
exchanges.text: A bishop in Granada, newly appointed to a see that did not exist two years ago, with a flock of fresh conversos he does not know and cannot watch—what resources does he have? What experience? The Inquisition you need in Granada does not yet exist, Your Majesty. It would need to be built.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Tell me more about how the inquisition in Aragon operates and how we may shape the inquisition in Grenada.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Torquemada settles back into his chair. His posture shifts subtly—the scholar now, the expert consulted on his field of knowledge.

exchanges.speaker: tomas_de_torquemada
exchanges.text: The Inquisition in Aragon operates under papal authority. Inquisitors are appointed by the Pope, or by the Inquisitor General acting in his name. They answer to Rome, not to the Crown. This has advantages. The inquisitor is not subject to local pressures—not the bishop who wishes to protect his flock's reputation, not the nobleman whose converso banker is too useful to lose, not the merchant guild that profits from trade with secret apostates.

exchanges.speaker: tomas_de_torquemada
exchanges.text: The tribunal operates through a system of denunciations, investigations, and trials. When the Inquisition arrives in a district, it proclaims an Edict of Grace—thirty days, sometimes forty, during which apostates may confess voluntarily and receive lenient penance. This separates the sincere penitent from the hardened deceiver.

exchanges.speaker: tomas_de_torquemada
exchanges.text: After the grace period, the work begins in earnest. Witnesses are called. Testimony is gathered. Patterns emerge—who attends Mass irregularly, who refuses certain foods, who observes strange customs behind closed doors. When sufficient evidence accumulates, the accused is summoned.

exchanges.speaker: tomas_de_torquemada
exchanges.text: For Granada, you would need to build this from nothing. The structures do not exist. The trained men do not exist. First—a chief inquisitor for the territory. A man of experience, not a local bishop distracted by a thousand other duties. Someone who understands the particular dangers of the Islamic apostate, which differ from the Jewish apostate in important ways. Second—familiares. Lay servants of the Inquisition who live among the people, who watch and listen and report. They must be trustworthy Christians of clean blood—no converso heritage themselves. Third—a network of informants. This need not be sinister, Your Majesty. Good Christians wish to report apostasy. They simply need to know that their reports will be heard, investigated, acted upon. Fourth—coordination with the secular arm. The Inquisition does not execute. It determines guilt and releases the unrepentant to secular authority for punishment.

exchanges.speaker: tomas_de_torquemada
exchanges.text: All of this takes years to build properly. But Granada is new. The conversions are fresh. If you wait too long, the apostates will learn to hide, will teach their children to hide, will create networks of deception that become impossible to penetrate. The time to plant this seed is now, Your Majesty. While the soil is still soft.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I see. I will follow up and install inquisition in Grenada upon my return. Now tell me, did you want to meet me because you wanted to impress the importance of Grenada upon me? Or was there something else you wanted to share?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Torquemada's expression shifts almost imperceptibly. Something like satisfaction crosses his gaunt features before vanishing behind monastic composure.

exchanges.speaker: tomas_de_torquemada
exchanges.text: Granada is important. But no—it is not why I asked for this meeting. I told your confessor that there are those in Rome who would speak with you away from Vatican eyes. I meant myself, yes. But I also meant to warn you.

exchanges.speaker: tomas_de_torquemada
exchanges.text: You come to Rome seeking audience with the Pope. You carry proposals from Como. You hope to find some middle ground between His Holiness and Basel. You are not the only one watching these developments, Your Majesty. And not all who watch wish you well.

exchanges.speaker: tomas_de_torquemada
exchanges.text: The French have agents in Rome. Cardinal d'Estouteville dines with the French ambassador weekly. The University of Paris sends men who are not merely theologians. They watch Basel. They watch the Emperor. And now they watch you. You marched six hundred men to St. Peter's this morning. By tonight, a report will travel north describing what you said, how you said it, how the Romans reacted. By next week, Cardinal d'Allemand in Basel will know every word.

exchanges.speaker: tomas_de_torquemada
exchanges.text: And there is talk, Your Majesty, among certain circles, that the King of Castile has grown too influential. That his crusade gives him moral authority that threatens the balance of power. That he should be... managed. I do not know what form this management might take. But I know that men are asking questions about your household. Your finances. Your conversos. Your intentions toward Aragon after Alfonso dies.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Ha! Let them. I carry on with my charge regardless. I was good to meet you, you have told me much about the inquisition. One last question; what happens to converso who have been found to still be muslim?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Torquemada pauses. His expression does not change, but something in his stillness suggests this question pleases him—a king who asks practical questions about consequences.

exchanges.speaker: tomas_de_torquemada
exchanges.text: That depends on the nature of their sin and the state of their soul. First—those who confess during the Edict of Grace, before any accusation is made. These receive light penance. Prayers, fasting, perhaps a pilgrimage. They are reconciled to the Church with minimal shame. This is mercy, Your Majesty. The door held open for the sincerely repentant.

exchanges.speaker: tomas_de_torquemada
exchanges.text: Second—those who confess after accusation but before trial concludes. These are reconciled, but with heavier penance. Public abjuration of their error. The sanbenito—a penitential garment worn for months or years, marking them so all may know. Fines. Sometimes imprisonment. Their names recorded, their descendants marked.

exchanges.speaker: tomas_de_torquemada
exchanges.text: Third—those who refuse to confess despite evidence, or who confess but are judged insincere, or who are convicted and later relapse into apostasy. These are relaxed to the secular arm. The Church does not kill, Your Majesty. She is a mother, and mothers do not slay their children. But when a child proves to be no child at all—a wolf that infiltrated the fold, a disease that threatens the flock—the Church must protect the faithful. She releases the unrepentant to secular authority, with a plea for mercy.

exchanges.speaker: tomas_de_torquemada
exchanges.text: The secular authority acts as it sees fit. In Aragon, the unrepentant burn. This is rare, Your Majesty. The purpose of the Inquisition is not execution—it is salvation. Every tool, every method, every procedure exists to give the apostate opportunity to repent and return to Christ. Only those who refuse every chance, who cling to their false faith unto the end, face the fire. And even then, those who repent at the stake—truly repent, in their final moments—are granted the mercy of strangulation before the flames are lit.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: You will find me a pious and faithful servant of the lord who seeks to expand christianity. I will remember this meeting. Good day, and walk with the lord sir. I go back to Lucia

encounters.recap: Brother Torquemada presents a systematic plan for establishing the Inquisition in Granada, detailing methods of surveillance, investigation, and punishment for Muslim converts suspected of secret apostasy. He warns Juan of French intelligence networks in Rome and positions himself as a valuable contact for implementing inquisitorial authority in newly conquered territories.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The walk back through Rome is quieter than the march to St. Peter's. Just you, Fray Hernando, and the two men-at-arms trailing behind. Fray Hernando says nothing for several streets. His sandals scuff against the cobblestones. His grey habit sways with each step. His face remains unreadable. Finally, as you pass the Pantheon's great bronze doors, he speaks—not looking at you, his voice carefully neutral.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: You told him you would install the Inquisition in Granada upon your return.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: It is not a question. It is not quite an accusation. It is simply a statement, placed in the air between you like a stone laid on a scale. He does not elaborate. He does not ask for explanation. He walks beside you in silence, waiting to see if you wish to discuss what just passed in that sparse Dominican cell—or if you wish to let it lie. The afternoon sun hangs over Rome. The palazzo is not far now.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Of course. Creating good christian rule with respect to both christians and muslims is important. I like the idea of an institution guiding souls to salvation. I dont like to burn people at the stake, even infidels, I will find something else. What do you think about the inquisition? I have not really met them.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Fray Hernando walks several more paces before responding. His sandals find each cobblestone with the deliberate care of a man choosing his words.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: The Inquisition is a lawful institution of Holy Mother Church. It has existed for two centuries. It has protected the faith from heresy—Cathars, Waldensians, others who would corrupt doctrine from within.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: His tone is measured. Factual. The voice of a man reciting what cannot be disputed. Then silence. More cobblestones. More careful steps.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: Dominicans staff the tribunals. They are trained for this work. Domini canes—the hounds of the Lord, they call themselves. Franciscans have a different charism. We preach. We beg. We live among the poor and trust that example teaches better than coercion.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He glances at you for the first time since leaving Santa Maria sopra Minerva.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: You say you will find something other than burning. This is good. But consider—you made a commitment to a man you met an hour ago. A man who told you what he wished you to hear. A man who clearly wants something, though he has not yet named his price. What do you know of Brother Tomás, Your Majesty? Beyond what Brother Tomás chose to reveal?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Maybe you are right. I will examine them thoroughly before installing them. If I then determine I do not want to install them, then so be it. I will have to swallow my words. We will be careful. I like Franciscans and their ways. Maybe Castille will have a Franciscanian inquisition, who knows?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Fray Hernando makes a sound—somewhere between a cough and a laugh, quickly suppressed.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: A Franciscan Inquisition. Brother Francis would spin in his grave at Assisi. We are not made for such work. We are made for begging bread and preaching to birds.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: But something in his posture eases. The tension that has held his shoulders since you left Torquemada's cell releases, just slightly.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: Examine them thoroughly. Yes. Speak to men who have lived under inquisitorial authority—not only the inquisitors themselves. Speak to the conversos in Toledo, in Seville. Ask them what the Inquisition means to those who are watched rather than those who watch.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He falls silent as you turn onto the street where the palazzo stands. The Castilian banner hangs limp in the afternoon stillness.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: I will say one more thing, Your Majesty, and then I will hold my peace on this matter.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He stops walking, turning to face you.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: Brother Tomás spoke of wolves in sheep's clothing. Of apostates hiding among the faithful. This is a real danger—I do not deny it. But there is another danger he did not mention. When shepherds see wolves everywhere, they begin to mistake sheep for wolves. And a shepherd who slaughters his own flock to protect it from wolves he imagines...

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He leaves the sentence unfinished.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: You are a good king, Your Majesty. You have a good heart. Guard it carefully in the days to come. Your queen is waiting. And I suspect she will want to know what a Dominican inquisitor wanted with her husband.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I lay my hand on his shoulder. I am glad to have you by my side Fray. Maybe we can find a way, a way towards salvation in a gentle way, through example. Who knows. I will never let you or your brothers do anything that is against your nature.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Fray Hernando is still beneath your hand. For a moment, his weathered face softens—the face of a man who has walked beside you through rebellion and crusade and the long bloody road to Granada.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: I know, Your Majesty. I have never doubted your heart.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He places his own hand briefly over yours—a gesture more intimate than any he has offered in the four years you have known him.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: It is not your heart that concerns me. It is the world that presses upon it. The men who whisper that harshness is strength. The voices that say mercy is weakness. You will hear such voices often in the years to come. More often as your power grows.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He steps back, composing himself. The confessor's mask settles back into place, but something warmer remains beneath it.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: Go to your wife. Hold your daughter. Remember what you fight for. And perhaps... do not mention Brother Tomás to Queen Lucia immediately. She has had a long morning watching from the Castel Sant'Angelo, wondering if her husband's hammer would crack the Vatican in two. Let her enjoy her relief before you tell her you have been discussing inquisitions with Dominicans.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He bows—shallow, familiar, the bow of a friend rather than a subject.

exchanges.speaker: fray_hernando
exchanges.text: I will be in the chapel if you need me. I find I have much to pray about.

encounters.recap: Walking back from meeting Torquemada, Fray Hernando cautiously questions Juan's promise to install the Inquisition in Granada. Through careful dialogue, the Franciscan friar warns against hasty commitments and suggests examining the institution thoroughly, advocating for gentler approaches to salvation. Their relationship deepens as Juan reassures him of his good intentions and values his counsel.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The palazzo is quiet in the afternoon heat. Servants move softly through the corridors, speaking in hushed tones. The household has learned the rhythms of a traveling court—when to bustle, when to fade into the walls.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: You find Lucia in your chambers, seated by the window where she can see the street below. She has changed from her morning clothes into a loose gown of Florentine blue, her hair unbound. A plate of bread and cheese sits beside her, barely touched. A cup of something—water, perhaps, or watered wine—rests in her hands.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: You are still in your armor. And you have not been arrested. These are both good signs.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She sets down her cup and rises, moving to you. Her hands find the straps of your breastplate, beginning to work them loose with practiced fingers.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: I watched from the Castel Sant'Angelo. The Medici agent arranged it—a room with a view of the piazza. I saw the march. I saw you speak, though I could not hear the words. I saw Catalina wave at the Vatican. And I saw someone wave back.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Tell me everything. From the beginning.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The armor comes off piece by piece—pauldrons, vambraces, greaves. Lucia works with the methodical patience of a woman who has done this before, though her fingers were not made for buckles and straps. She listens without interrupting as you speak.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: You describe the mass. Canon Della Rovere's careful neutrality. The elderly cardinal who ignored you. The papal secretaries with their notebooks. The prayers for the seventy-five, brief but dignified. Catalina's behavior—better than expected. The speech in the piazza. The Roman whispers afterward. The butcher who spoke loudly of faith versus politics. The curious crowd that lingered without cheering.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: She told me. Three times. The Pope waved at her specifically, she is certain of it.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Then you describe the Dominican. Lucia's hands slow on the final buckles as you tell of Brother Tomás de Torquemada. The sparse cell. The dark eyes. The questions about conversos, about Commander Martín, about how you know a conversion is genuine. She sets aside the last piece of armor and moves to pour you wine. Her back is to you when you describe Torquemada's proposals—records of every conversion, observation, informants, investigation. The Inquisition that Granada does not yet have but would need to build.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She is silent when you tell her you said you would install the Inquisition upon your return. You describe the warnings about French agents. Cardinal d'Estouteville. Reports traveling north. Men asking questions about your household, your finances, your intentions toward Aragon.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: This Dominican. He sought you out. He had answers ready for questions you had not yet thought to ask. He told you exactly what you needed to hear about Granada's future, and then—conveniently—warned you about enemies watching. In Florence, we call this l'amo. The hook. You bait it with something the fish wants. Then you set it with something the fish fears. And then you wait for the fish to swim exactly where you wish it to go. What does Brother Tomás want, husband? He did not arrange this meeting from the kindness of his heart.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I discussed this with Fray Hernando as well. I will not burn infidels at the stake. I will start an institution to help souls reach salvation, but more in a Franciscanic way I think. How, I'm not sure yet.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: That is what you will not do. And that is what you hope to build. These are good things to know. But I did not ask what you intend, husband. I asked what he intends. What Brother Tomás wants. A man does not position himself as indispensable to a king—offering expertise, offering warnings, offering to build institutions—without wanting something in return.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She rises and moves to the window, looking out at the Roman afternoon.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: In Florence, when a man offers you exactly what you need before you knew you needed it, you ask yourself: what does he gain when I accept? Not what he says he gains. What he actually gains. You told him you would install the Inquisition in Granada. You told him you liked his ideas about records and observation. You listened when he warned you about French agents. What did you offer him, Juan? What did he walk away with? Does he now return to his masters—whoever they are—and say 'The King of Castile is ours'?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I think he wants more or less what everyone wants. Power, position, prestige. Through me as king. I will examine the inquisition when I return. If needed, I will retract what I told him today. We will see. I have given him nothing I cannot take back.

encounters.recap: Juan returns to Lucia and recounts his eventful day in Rome, including his encounter with Brother Tomás de Torquemada and his agreement to install an Inquisition in Granada. Lucia displays her Florentine political instincts, warning Juan that the Dominican may be manipulating him and questioning what the friar truly wants in return for his counsel.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Casual meetings are possible. The churches, the markets, the public spaces where one might happen to encounter someone. Cardinal Capranica has not approached us. But he has also not avoided us. He appeared at Mass this morning—that was not accident.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Let me think on it while you find oranges. I will write to our family's agent again. Ask who might be... approachable. Who attends which churches, which markets, which social gatherings.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Now go. Before I decide I want figs as well, and you must search all of Rome.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The afternoon air is warm as you step into the Roman streets. Without armor, without guards, without the trappings of kingship, you are simply a man in good Spanish wool—foreign, clearly, but unremarkable. Captain Fernán would be furious if he knew. You do not care.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The market near the Pantheon is a riot of color and noise. Vendors call their wares in rapid Italian, competing for attention. Bolts of cloth hang beside strings of garlic. A fishmonger argues with a priest over the price of sardines. Children dart between legs, chasing a spotted cat.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: You find the fruit sellers in a corner of the piazza, their stalls bright with the harvest of southern Italy. Lemons from Amalfi. Figs from Calabria. And oranges—piles of them, some pale and golden, others dark as wine.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The walk back is slower. You take a longer route, through narrow streets where laundry hangs between buildings and old men play cards in doorways. Rome layers itself around you—ancient stones beneath medieval walls beneath Renaissance facades. A city that has seen a hundred kings come and go.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Near the palazzo, you pass a group of men talking in low voices. One of them glances at you, does a double-take, nudges his companion. You catch a fragment: '...il re spagnolo...' The Spanish king. Word has spread.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Lucia is dozing when you return, curled in her chair by the window. The afternoon light falls soft across her face, smoothing the lines of worry and weariness. One hand rests on her belly.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: You found them?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The knife works slowly. You are not skilled at this—there are servants for such things, and before that there were cooks, and before that your mother never let you near sharp instruments. But you manage. The skin comes away in uneven strips, revealing the flesh beneath. Dark as garnets, the old woman said. She was right. The orange bleeds crimson where your knife has nicked it, juice running down your fingers.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Sweet. And tart. Perfect.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: You are very bad at this, husband.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: Sit with me. Share them. We have perhaps an hour before Catalina wakes and demands attention. Let us have this.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The afternoon light slants golden through the window. Rome murmurs beyond the walls. For this moment, there is only the taste of blood oranges and the quiet company of your wife.

encounters.recap: Juan ventures alone into Rome's markets to buy oranges for Lucia, enjoying the anonymity of walking without guards or royal trappings. He purchases blood oranges from an old Sicilian woman and returns to find Lucia resting. They share the oranges together in a tender domestic moment, with Lucia skillfully peeling the fruit while they enjoy a rare hour of peaceful intimacy before their daughter wakes.
